awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  ATD:  Statistical Detection of New Patterns and Potential Threats in Geospatial Sequences of Social and Political Events
awd_abstract_narration:
The project focuses on the statistical detection and interpretation of new trends and geospatial pattern changes in sequences of social and political events. Millions of such events occur on a local, regional, national, and international scale. They are being recorded in publicly available domains, fed from a multitude of sources, from news media to social media, blogs, and tweets. Events include civic unrests, demonstrations, crimes, arrests, human rights activities, political conflicts, protests, cyber attacks, terrorist activities, publication of news, their analyses and discussions, and so on. Such events occur at random times, while their location, size, and consequences involve a lot of uncertainty. An abrupt change of pattern, appearance of a new distribution or trend is typically caused by a new circumstance that may represent a potential threat. For the prompt detection of such threats, sensitive yet reliable and computationally feasible statistical algorithms for change-point detection in geospatial sequences will be elaborated, followed by social, economic, and political interpretation of statistically detectable changes. The project will provide general tools for the prompt reaction to threatening anomalies identified in large continuously monitored databases, with a special focus on new patterns that represent potential threats to homeland security.

Quick detection of sudden changes and unexpectedly appearing new trends is crucially important for the prompt reaction to potential security threats. To handle large data sets of high dimension in change-point detection problems, to combine simultaneously observed geospatial sequences of event data, and to develop computationally feasible algorithms for fast threat detection, three general approaches are exploited: (1) recursive change-point detection algorithms that are updated with each new data point while storing and processing minimum required information at each step; (2) auxiliary change-point warning schemes represented by computationally inexpensive and fast algorithms for the early detection of potential threats; (3) sequentially planned change-point detection algorithms that invoke the main detection scheme at the special interim time points only, and (4) maximum use of prior information by means of Bayesian detection algorithms.

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on modeling, statistical detection, classification, and interpretation of sudden changes in patterns of events in time and space, with a special focus on events that represent potential threats. Novel methods and the supporting theory are developed for a number of general situations including

(1)   Spatio-temporal point processes that form a random field;

(2)   Temporary (transient) pattern changes that are known to end, returning to the initial pattern;

(3)   Multi-compartmental count models with broadly missing data and unobserved states.

 

Special applications of the new methods are elaborated for the following situations and data that can reflect potential social, natural, and epidemiological threats:

(1)   Crime, violence, and police activity; the 911 emergency calls data in major US cities;

(2)   Wild forest fires; Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) data from the state of California;

(3)   COVID-19 pandemics; morbidity, mortality, and vaccination counts from Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX).

 

Theory, Methods, and Applications

 

1. Spatio-temporal point processes of events.


Anisotropic Markov random field models are elaborated and analyzed to reflect the development of social, political, and other types of events in time and space. The model parameters quantify the speed, direction, and coordination of the appearing patterns of events. Groups of canonical parameters represent the main and interaction effects, and in particular, answer a question whether the events are occurring spontaneously or in a dependent and possibly coordinated way.

 

The project extended the theory of Markov random fields to the new neighborhood structure that captures the spread of events in time and space. Canonical parameters are established, and conditional distribution and pseudo-likelihood functions are derived explicitly. Based on these results, the generalized maximum pseudolikelihood estimation and significant testing methods are developed, with a clear interpretation of significant effects in terms of the intensity, direction, and appearing new trends. Short term forecasts are produced that indicate good performance, evaluated by cross-validation. These methods are applied to the estimation and detection of pattern changes and different types of threats caused by wild forest fires and by social unrest.

 

2.      Transient change-point detection.


Periods of unrest and threatening signals usually alternate with segments from the original base distribution. Optimal methods are developed for the detection of multiple transient (temporary) changes, where the initial distribution changes at unknown times and later returns to the original state. Assuming an unknown number of transient changes, moments of change, and durations of each segment, a change-point estimation algorithm is derived that controls the familywise rate of false alarms. That is, the probability of triggering at least one false alarm during a given long interval is guaranteed to be bounded by a pre-assigned low value. Algorithms are developed to be applied retrospectively or off-line, analyzing data already collected in the past, as well as sequentially or on-line, detecting change-points in the real-time data as soon as possible after they occur, while controlling for the rate of false alarms.

 

3.      Compartmental count models for the study of epidemic trends.


This part of the project was motivated by the COVID-19 pandemic that broke out in the middle of the project timeline. It appeared that spatio-temporal Markov count models studied in the project can be extended to the officially reported daily counts of infected, tested, recovered, perished, and vaccinated people in different territories. It also became evident that the official counts are underestimated because a substantial portion of infected people is not tested, many recovered cases are not reported, and the proportion of unobserved and under-observed counts changes in time and varies by territory. The new multi-compartmental stochastic model extended the classical SIR model to include additional compartments and allow its multiple parameters vary continuously in time. These parameters include the infection rate, the testing rate, the recovery rate, the mortality rate, the vaccination rate, and the recovery reporting rate. The proposed Bayesian algorithm uses observed and reported counts to estimate the model parameters and unobserved counts, continuously updating the estimates with new data. This research allows to estimate the missing counts and the real spread of the pandemic, to determine changes of patterns, and to produce short-term forecasts, including threatening situations. Methods are applied to the COVID-19 pandemic and the seasonal flu epidemics, and they can be extended to the study of other infectious diseases.

 

The project engaged graduate students including members of underrepresented groups. Results were presented at fourteen national and international conferences and seminars and submitted journal publications, with more submissions and conference presentations forthcoming.
